{{Infobox person | name = Hoover | image = | image_size = 200px | caption = | birth_date = {{circa|1971}} | birth_place = | death_date = {{death date|1985|7|25|mf=y}} | death_place = [[New England Aquarium]]
[[Boston, Massachusetts]], [[United States|U.S.]] | occupation = | spouse = | parents = | children = 6{{cite news| last = Currier | first = Patricia A. | coauthors = | title = Hoover Will Talk No More; A Delight To Thousands, Aquarium Seal Dies At Age 14 | work = [[The Boston Globe]] | pages = 2 | publisher = | date = July 26, 1985 | url = http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?did=662073171&sid=1&Fmt=3&clientId=3589&RQT=309&VName=PQD | accessdate = 2006-12-18}} }} '''Hoover''' ({{circa|1971}} – July 25, 1985) was a [[harbor seal]] who was able to imitate basic [[human speech]].{{cite journal | last = Fitch | first = W. Tecumseh | title = The evolution of speech: a comparative review | journal = Trends in Cognitive Sciences | volume = 4 | issue = 7 | pages = 258–267 | date = 2000-07-01 | url = http://www.st-andrews.ac.uk/~wtsf/Fitch2000TICS.pdf | publisher = Elsvier Ltd | format = [[PDF]] | doi = 10.1016/S1364-6613(00)01494-7 | accessdate = 2006-12-11 | pmid = 10859570 | issn = 1364-6613 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050308074038/http://www.st-andrews.ac.uk/~wtsf/Fitch2000TICS.pdf |archivedate=2005-03-08}} == Cundy’s Harbor == On May 5, 1971,{{cite web |url= http://h2g2.com/edited_entry/A27019569 |publisher=''Auditory Neuroscience'' |date=Sep 27, 2007 |author= N/A |title=Fame at the Aquarium |accessdate=September 7, 2016 }} Scottie Dunning discovered a tiny male harbor seal pup on the shore of Cundy’s Harbor, [[Maine]]. After a failed attempt at locating the pup’s mother, Dunning called his brother-in-law George Swallow for help. When Swallow arrived, the two searched for the mother seal and later found her dead among the rocks.{{cite book |last=Swallow |first=Alice Dunning |date=2001 |title=Hoover the Seal, and George |url=https://www.amazon.com/Hoover-George-Alice-Dunning-Swallow/dp/B008JBS9ZU/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1473266266&sr=8-1&keywords=hoover+the+seal+and+george+swallow |location=Maine |publisher=Freeport Village Press |pages=3–7 |isbn=0615895352 }} After careful consideration, Swallow finally decided to take the seal pup home with him. At first, it refused to drink milk from a bottle, but once advice was given by a neighbor to grind up fish and offer it to the pup, he sucked it up like a hoover ([[vacuum cleaner]]), hence his name. The Swallows kept him in their bathtub, but this proved too inconvenient within a few days. So George moved him out back to a spring-fed pond where he set up a “pup tent” enclosed by a wire fence. Hoover lived very much like a family dog and even accompanied George riding into town with his head poking out of the window. As Hoover grew, so did his appetite, and the Swallows found themselves contracting a firm in [[Portland, Maine]], to supply them with enough fish. The Swallows spoke to the seal pup constantly.{{cite web |url= http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/1983/01/03/hoover |publisher=The New Yorker |date=January 3, 1983 |author=Anthony Hiss |title=Talk of the Town HOOVER| accessdate=September 7, 2016 }} Alice Swallow recalls in her book, ''Hoover the Seal and George'': “If George was late in giving Hoover his breakfast [he] found his way up to the back steps … George would yell, “Hello, there.” George and Hoover were great friends. Sometimes Hoover would hide … and would not appear until George yelled, “Get out of there and come over here!” Then Hoover would come out of hiding and rush over to George and greet him with a wet, fishy kiss.” It was during this time that Hoover began to mimic George’s thick, gruff accent and catchphrases. Soon, however, the Swallows reluctantly decided they could not keep Hoover, due to his increasing growth and enormous fish intake. In August, they contacted the [[New England Aquarium]], who agreed to accept Hoover at their facility. == New England Aquarium == Upon their arrival, George informed the Aquarium staff that Hoover could talk, but none of the attendants believed him so he did not press the point. It wasn’t until 5 years later, as an adult seal, that Hoover became comfortable with his surroundings at the Aquarium and began to utter phrases such as: “Hello, there!” and “Come Over Here!” in a thick [[New England]] [[accent (sociolinguistics)|accent]] similar to Swallow’s.{{cite web |url= https://auditoryneuroscience.com/content/hoover-talking-seal |publisher=''Auditory Neuroscience'' |date=September 2, 2007 |author= Jan Schnupp |title=Hoover the Talking Seal|accessdate=September 7, 2016 }} On account of this unique feature, Hoover became famous and appeared along with the Swallows in publications such as ''[[Reader’s Digest]]'' and ''[[The New Yorker]]'' and the television program ''[[Good Morning, America]]''. == Death == Hoover died on July 25, 1985, due to complications during his annual [[molt]]. His [[obituary]] was published in ''[[The Boston Globe]]''.{{cite news | title = The Smartest City on the Planet | work = Boston Magazine | date = October 2006 }} == Legacy == None of Hoover's six pups (daughters Joey, Amelia, and Trumpet and sons Lucifer, Cinder, and Spark){{cite news| last = Currier | first = Patricia A. | coauthors = | title = Hoover Will Talk No More; A Delight To Thousands, Aquarium Seal Dies At Age 14 | work = [[The Boston Globe]] | pages = 2 | publisher = | date = July 26, 1985 | url = http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?did=662073171&sid=1&Fmt=3&clientId=3589&RQT=309&VName=PQD | accessdate = 2006-12-18}} spoke, but his grandson Chacoda (or "Chucky") has shown an ability to be guided in his vocalizations. As of 2007, Chucky remains vocal but has not shown an ability to mimic human speech. Aquarium staff continue to work with him.{{cite web |url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/articles/2007/09/02/chuck_the_seal_has_a_lot_to_say/ |publisher=''The Boston Globe'' |date=September 2, 2007 |author=Rebecca A. Fitzgerald |title=Chuck the seal has a lot to say }}{{cite news | title = Ask the Globe | work = The Boston Globe | pages = 56 | date = April 19, 1989 }} ==In popular culture== On the British comedy panel game show ''[[QI]]'' (''Quite Interesting''), host [[Stephen Fry]] asked the question: “What is meant by the expression "Hoover the talking seal”?” Panelist Roger McGough answered, “Well, it's either one of those wonderful [[Australian English|Oz]] expressions for throwing up: Excuse me, I've got to go hoover the talking seal”; to which Fry replied: “...or my wife came in just as I was hoovering the talking seal.” In 2013, Derek Kaloust and Anna Tillett wrote a children’s book about Hoover and the Swallows entitled ''Hoover the Talking Seal''.{{cite web |url=http://hooverthetalkingseal.com/hoover-the-talking-seals-history/ |publisher=Talking Seal Productions |date=2013 |author=Derek Kaloust |title=Hoover the Talking Seal }} ==See also== {{Col-begin|width=}} {{Col-break}} *[[Batyr]] *[[Vocal learning]] *[[Talking animal]] *[[Koko (gorilla)|Koko]] {{Col-break}} {{Listen|filename=Mgm Hoover the talking seal.ogg|title=Hoover the talking seal|description=Sample of Hoover's speech|format=[[Ogg]]}} {{Col-end}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hoover}} [[Category:1971 animal births]] [[Category:1985 animal deaths]] [[Category:Individual seals and sea lions]] [[Category:Talking animals]] [[Category:Individual animals in the United States]]

[[File:Germination-en.svg|thumb|335px|Epigeal vs. hypogeal germination]] '''Hypogeal germination''' (from [[Ancient Greek]] {{lang|grc|ὑπόγειος}} [{{grc-tr|ὑπόγειος}}] 'below ground', from {{lang|grc|ὑπό}} [{{grc-tr|ὑπό}}] 'below' and {{lang|grc|γῆ}} [{{grc-tr|γῆ}}] 'earth, ground') is a [[botanical]] term indicating that the [[germination]] of a plant takes place below the ground. An example of a plant with hypogeal germination is the [[pea]] (''Pisum sativum''). The opposite of hypogeal is [[epigeal germination|epigeal]] (above-ground germination).
==Germination== Hypogeal germination implies that the [[cotyledon]]s stay below the ground. The [[epicotyl]] (part of the [[plant stem|stem]] above the cotyledon) grows, while the [[hypocotyl]] (part of the stem below the cotyledon) stays the same length. In this way, the epicotyl pushes the [[plumule]] above the ground.
Normally, the cotyledon is fleshy, and contains many nutrients that are used for germination. No [[photosynthesis]] takes place within the cotyledon.<ref name="tropecol">Parolin, P., Ferreira, L.V., Junk, W.J. (2003) [http://tropecol.com/pdf/open/PDF_44_2/44203.pdf "Germination characteristics and establishment of trees from central Amazonian flood plains"] ''Tropical Ecology'' '''44'''(2): 157-169</ref>
Because the cotyledon stays below the ground, it is much less vulnerable to for example night-frost <ref>Rigetti, S. (1998) ''[http://ecommons.usask.ca/bitstream/handle/10388/etd-05222012-132102/Rigetti_Sara_Catharine_1998_sec.pdf Weed control in direct-seeded pea and lentil]'' University of Saskatchewan</ref> or [[grazing]]. The evolutionary strategy is that the plant produces a relatively low number of seeds, but each seed has a bigger chance of surviving.
Plants that show hypogeal germination need relatively little in the way of external nutrients to grow, therefore they are more frequent on nutrient-poor soils. The plants also need less sunlight, so they can be found more often in the middle of forests, where there is much competition to reach the sunlight.<ref name="tropecol"/>
Plants that show hypogeal germination grow relatively slowly, especially in the first phase. In areas that are regularly flooded, they need more time between floodings to develop. On the other hand, they are more resistant when a flooding takes place.<ref name="tropecol"/> After the slower first phase, the plant develops faster than plants that show epigeal germination.
It is possible that within the same [[genus]] one species shows hypogeal germination while another species shows epigeal germination. Some genera in which this happens are: *''[[Phaseolus]]'': the runner bean (''[[Phaseolus coccineus]]'') shows hypogeal germination, whereas the common bean (''[[Phaseolus vulgaris]]'') shows epigeal germination *''[[Lilium]]'': see [[Lily seed germination types]] *''[[Araucaria]]'': species in the section ''Araucaria'' show hypogeal germination, whereas species in the section ''Eutacta'' show epigeal germination
==Phanerocotylar vs. cryptocotylar== In 1965, botanist [[James A. Duke]] introduced the terms [[cryptocotylar]] and [[phanerocotylar]] as synonyms for hypogeal and epigeal respectively, because he didn't consider these terms etymologically correct.<ref>Duke, J.A. (1965) "Keys for the identification of seedlings of some prominent woody species in 8 forest types in Puerto Rico" ''Ann. Missouri. Bot. Gard'' no. 52 pp. 314-350</ref> Later, it was discovered that there are rare cases of species where the germination is epigeal and cryptocotylar.<ref>Franceschini, M. (2004) "An unusual case of epigeal cryptocotylar germination in ''Rollinia salicifolia'' (Annonaceae)" ''Botanical Journal of the Linnean Society'' vol. 146 no. 1</ref>{{clarification needed|date=August 2014}} Therefore, divisions have been proposed that take both factors into account.<ref>Garwood, N.C. (1996) "Functional morphology of tropical tree seedlings", in: ''The ecology of tropical forest tree seedlings'', pp. 59-129. New York: Swaine</ref>

{{Other uses of|Individual mobility|Social identity theory}} {{Network Science}} Individual [[mobilities|human mobility]] is the study that describes how individual humans move within a network or system.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Keyfitz |first1=Nathan |title=Individual Mobility in a Stationary Population |journal=Population Studies |volume=27 |issue=July 1, 1973 |pages=335–352 |doi=10.2307/2173401 |jstor=2173401 |publisher=Taylor & Francis, Ltd.}}</ref> The concept has been researched by a number of fields originating in the study of demographics. Understanding human mobility has many applications in diverse areas, including [[spread of diseases]],<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Colizza | first1 = V. | last2 = Barrat | first2 = A. | last3 = Barthélémy | first3 = M. | last4 = Valleron | first4 = A.-J. | last5 = Vespignani | first5 = A. | year = 2007 | title = Modeling the worldwide spread of pandemic influenza: baseline case and containment interventions | PMC=1779816 | journal = PLoS Medicine | volume = 4 | issue = | pages = 95–110 | pmid=17253899 | doi=10.1371/journal.pmed.0040013}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Hufnagel | first1 = L. | last2 = Brockmann | first2 = D. | last3 = Geisel | first3 = T. | year = 2004 | title = Forecast and control of epidemics in a globalized world | url = | journal = Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA | volume = 101 | issue = | pages = 15124–15129 | doi=10.1073/pnas.0308344101| arxiv = cond-mat/0410766 | bibcode = 2004PNAS..10115124H }}</ref> [[mobile virus]]es,<ref>Epidemic spreading in scale-free networks. R Pastor-Satorras, A Vespignani - Physical review letters, 2001</ref> [[city planning]],<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Horner | first1 = M. W. | last2 = O'Kelly | first2 = M. E. S | year = 2001 | title = Embedding economies of scale concepts for hub networks design | url = | journal = J. Transp. Geogr | volume = 9 | issue = | pages = 255–265 | doi=10.1016/s0966-6923(01)00019-9}}</ref><ref>Inferring land use from mobile phone activity JL Toole, M Ulm, MC González, D Bauer - Proceedings of the ACM SIGKDD international …, 2012</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Rozenfeld | first1 = H. D. | display-authors = 1 | last2 = et al | year = 2008 | title = Laws of population growth | doi = 10.1073/pnas.0807435105 | journal = Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA | volume = 105 | issue = | pages = 18702–18707 | arxiv = 0808.2202 | bibcode = 2008PNAS..10518702R }}</ref> [[traffic engineering (transportation)|traffic engineering]],<ref>P Wang, T Hunter, AM Bayen, K Schechtner "Understanding road usage patterns in urban areas" ''Scientific reports'', 2012</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Krings | first1 = G. | last2 = Calabrese | first2 = F. | last3 = Ratti | first3 = C. | last4 = Blondel | first4 = V. D. | year = | title = Urban gravity: A model for inter-city telecommunication flows | url = | journal = J. Stat. Mech.-Theor. Exp. | volume = L07003 | issue = | page = 2009 }}</ref> [[financial market forecasting]],<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Gabaix | first1 = X. | last2 = Gopikrishnan | first2 = P. | last3 = Plerou | first3 = V. | last4 = Stanley | first4 = H. E. | year = 2003 | title = A theory of power-law distributions in financial market fluctuations | url = | journal = Nature | volume = 423 | issue = | pages = 267–270 | doi=10.1038/nature01624 | pmid=12748636| bibcode = 2003Natur.423..267G }}</ref> and [[nowcasting (economics)|nowcasting]] of economic [[well-being]].<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://www.degruyter.com/view/j/jos.2015.31.issue-2/jos-2015-0017/jos-2015-0017.xml|title = Small Area Model-Based Estimators Using Big Data Sources|last = Stefano Marchetti|date = Jun 2015|journal = Journal of Official Statistics|doi = 10.1515/jos-2015-0017|pmid = |access-date = |display-authors=etal|volume=31}}</ref><ref>L. Pappalardo et al., [https://www.researchgate.net/publication/282869681_Using_Big_Data_to_study_the_link_between_human_mobility_and_socio-economic_development Using Big Data to study the link between human mobility and socio-economic development], Proceedings of the 2015 IEEE International conference on Big Data, Santa Clara, CA, USA, 2015.</ref>
== Data == In recent years, there has been a surge in large data sets available on human movements. These data sets are usually obtained from [[cell phone tracking|cell phone]] or [[GPS tracking|GPS]] data, with varying degrees of accuracy. For example, cell phone data is usually recorded whenever a call or a text message has been made or received by the user, and contains the location of the tower that the phone has connected to as well as the time stamp.<ref name=marta /> In urban areas, user and the telecommunication tower might be only a few hundred meters away from each other, while in rural areas this distance might well be in region of a few kilometers. Therefore, there is varying degree of accuracy when it comes to locating a person using cell phone data. These datasets are anonymized by the phone companies so as to hide and protect the identity of actual users. As example of its usage, researchers <ref name=marta /> used the trajectory of 100,000 cell phone users within a period of six months, while in much larger scale <ref name=song /> trajectories of three million cell phone users were analyzed. GPS data are usually much more accurate even though they usually are, because of [[privacy]] concerns, much harder to acquire. Massive amounts of GPS data describing human mobility are produced, for example, by on-board GPS devices on private vehicles.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|url = http://www.nature.com/ncomms/2015/150908/ncomms9166/full/ncomms9166.html|title = Returners and Explorers dichotomy in Human Mobility|last = Luca Pappalardo|date = 8 September 2015|journal = Nature Communications|doi = 10.1038/ncomms9166|pmid = 26349016|volume = 6|display-authors=etal|pages=8166|pmc=4569739|bibcode=2015NatCo...6E8166P}}</ref> The GPS device automatically turns on when the vehicle starts, and the sequence of GPS points the device produces every few seconds forms a detailed mobility trajectory of the vehicle. Some recent scientific studies compared the mobility patterns emerged from mobile phone data with those emerged from GPS data.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref>L. Pappalardo et al., [http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/login.jsp?tp=&arnumber=6855925&url=http%3A%2F%2Fieeexplore.ieee.org%2Fxpls%2Fabs_all.jsp%3Farnumber%3D6855925 Comparing general mobility and mobility by car], BRICS Countries Congress (BRICS-CCI) and 11th Brazilian Congress (CBIC) on Computational Intelligence, 2013.</ref>
Researchers have been able to extract very detailed information about the people whose data are made available to public. This has sparked a great amount of concern about privacy issues. As an example of liabilities that might happen, [[New York City]] released 173 million individual [[taxi]] trips. City officials used a very weak [[cryptography algorithm]] to anonymize the license number and medallion number, which is an alphanumeric code assigned to each taxi cab.<ref name=gawker>{{cite web|url=http://gawker.com/the-public-nyc-taxicab-database-that-accidentally-track-1646724546 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-11-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141118175119/http://gawker.com/the-public-nyc-taxicab-database-that-accidentally-track-1646724546 |archivedate=2014-11-18 |df= }}</ref> This made it possible for hackers to completely de-anonymize the dataset, and even some were able to extract detailed information about specific passengers and celebrities, including their origin and destination and how much they tipped.<ref name=gawker /><ref>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/jun/27/new-york-taxi-details-anonymised-data-researchers-warn</ref>
== Characteristics == At the large scale, when the behaviour is modelled over a period of relatively long duration (e.g. more than one day), human mobility can be described by three major components: * trip distance distribution <math> P(r) </math> * radius of [[gyration]] <math> r_g (t)</math> * number of visited locations <math> S(t) </math>
Brockmann,<ref>The scaling laws of human travel. D Brockmann, L Hufnagel, T Geisel - Nature, 2006 - nature.com</ref> by analysing banknotes, found that the probability of travel distance follows a [[scale-free network|scale-free]] [[random walk]] known as [[Lévy flight]] of form <math> P(r)\ \sim r^{-(1+\beta)} </math> where <math>\beta =0.6 </math>. This was later confirmed by two studies that used cell phone data<ref name=marta /> and GPS data to track users.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|url = https://link.springer.com/article/10.1140%2Fepjst%2Fe2013-01715-5|title = Understanding the patterns of car travel|last = Luca Pappalardo|date = 29 January 2013|journal = European Physical Journal ST|doi = 10.1140/epjst/e2013-01715-5|pmid = |access-date = |volume = 215|issue = 1|display-authors=etal|pages=61–73|bibcode = 2013EPJST.215...61P}}</ref> The implication of this model is that, as opposed to other more traditional forms of random walks such as [[brownian motion]], human trips tend to be of mostly short distances with a few long distance ones. In brownian motion, the distribution of trip distances are govern by a bell-shaped curve, which means that the next trip is of a roughly predictable size, the average, where in Lévy flight it might be an order of magnitude larger than the average.
Some people are inherently inclined to travel longer distances than the average, and the same is true for people with lesser urge for movement. Radius of gyration is used to capture just that and it indicates the characteristic distance travelled by a person during a time period t.<ref name=marta>Understanding individual human mobility patterns MC Gonzalez, CA Hidalgo, AL Barabasi - Nature, 2008</ref> Each user, within his radius of gyration <math> r_g (t)</math>, will choose his trip distance according to <math> P(r) </math>.
The third component models the fact that humans tend to visit some locations more often than what would have happened under a random scenario. For example, home or workplace or favorite restaurants are visited much more than many other places in a user's radius of gyration. It has been discovered that <math> S(t)\ \sim t^{\mu} </math> where <math> \mu = 0.6 </math>, which indicates a sublinear growth in different number of places visited by an individual . These three measures capture the fact that most trips happen between a limited number of places, with less frequent travels to places outside of an individual's radius of gyration.
== Predictability == Although the human mobility is modeled as a random process, it is surprisingly predictable. By measuring the entropy of each person's movement, it has been shown <ref name=song>Limits of predictability in human mobility. C Song, Z Qu, N Blumm, AL Barabási - Science, 2010</ref> that there is a 93% potential predictability. This means that although there is a great variance in type of users and the distances that each of them travel, the overall characteristic of them is highly predictable. Implication of it is that in principle, it is possible to accurately model the processes that are dependent on human mobility patterns, such as disease or mobile virus spreading patterns.<ref name=airtransportation>A metric of influential spreading during contagion dynamics through the air transportation network C Nicolaides, L Cueto-Felgueroso, MC González… - PLoS ONE, 2012</ref><ref name=phonevirus>Understanding the spreading patterns of mobile phone viruses P Wang, MC González, CA Hidalgo, AL Barabási - Science, 2009</ref><ref>Colizza, V., Barrat, A., Barthélemy, M. & Vespignani, A. Predictability and epidemic pathways in global outbreaks of infectious diseases: The SARS case study. BMC Med. 5, 34 (2007)</ref>
On individual scale, daily human mobility can be explained by only 17 [[Network motif]]s. Each individual, shows one of these motifs characteristically, over a period of several months. This opens up the possibility to reproduce daily individual mobility using a tractable analytical model<ref>Unravelling daily human mobility motifs CM Schneider, V Belik, T Couronné, Z Smoreda… - Journal of The Royal Society Interface, 2013</ref>
== Applications == [[Infectious disease]]s spread across the globe usually because of long-distance travels of carriers of the disease. These long-distance travels are made using [[air transport]]ation systems and it has been shown that "[[network topology]], traffic structure, and individual mobility patterns are all essential for accurate predictions of disease spreading".<ref name=airtransportation/> On a smaller spatial scale the regularity of human movement patterns and its temporal structure should be taken into account in models of infectious disease spread.<ref name=commuting>V Belik, T Geisel, D Brockmann, Natural human mobility patterns and spatial spread of infectious diseases. Phys. Rev. X, 2011</ref> Cellphone viruses that are transmitted via bluetooth are greatly dependent on the human interaction and movements. With more people using similar operating systems for their cellphones, it's becoming much easier to have a virus epidemic.<ref name=phonevirus />
In [[Transportation Planning]], leveraging the characteristics of human movement, such as tendency to travel short distances with few but regular bursts of long-distance trips, novel improvements have been made to [[Trip distribution]] models, specifically to [[Gravity model of migration]] <ref>A universal model for mobility and migration patterns F Simini, MC González, A Maritan, AL Barabási - Nature, 2012</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Joan Robinson Hill | image = Joan Robinson and Beloved Belinda 1953.jpg | alt = Joan Robinson and her horse, Beloved Belinda, 1953 | caption = Joan Robinson and her horse, Beloved Belinda, 1953 | birth_name = Joan Olive Robinson | birth_date = {{Birth date|1931|02|06}}{{cite web|url=https://familysearch.org/pal:/MM9.1.1/KS1C-GNL|title=Texas Deaths, 1890-1976-Joan Robinson Hill|publisher=FamilySearch.org|accessdate=August 2, 2014}} | birth_place = [[Houston, Texas]], US | death_date = {{Death date and age|1969|03|19|1931|02|06}} | death_place = Houston, Texas, US | nationality = American | spouse = John Hill (1957-1969; her death) | occupation = [[Equestrianism|Equestrian]], [[socialite]] | known_for = National competitor in equestrian events
Death in unexplained circumstances}} '''Joan Olive Robinson Hill''' (February 6, 1931 – March 19, 1969) was a [[socialite]] and [[equestrianism|equestrian]] from [[Houston, Texas]]. Her unexplained death at age 38 led to her husband, John Hill, becoming the first person to be indicted by the state of Texas on the charge of murder by omission. The case precipitated a series of events that included the 1972 murder of John Hill and, two years later, the fatal police shooting of the man accused of that murder. Adopted as an infant by wealthy oil tycoon Davis "Ash" Robinson and his wife, Rhea, Joan became an equestrian at a young age. She excelled and continued the sport into adulthood, ultimately winning several national titles. After two youthful marriages that ended in divorce, Joan married [[plastic surgeon]] John Hill in 1957. After a tumultuous marriage, she died following a short illness on March 19, 1969. Autopsy examinations failed to determine a cause of death beyond an infection from an unknown source. Ash subsequently accused John of poisoning Joan, and petitioned the district attorney to prosecute John for murder. John's murder trial was held in February 1971 but ended in a mistrial. As a second trial was approaching, John was gunned down by an intruder at his home. A suspect, Bobby Wayne Vandiver, was arrested and indicted for the murder, but was killed in a shootout with police before his trial. Two other suspects, Marcia McKittrick and Lilla Paulus, were convicted as accomplices to John's murder and served time in prison. The case was the subject of [[Thomas Thompson (American author)|Thomas Thompson]]'s 1976 book ''Blood and Money'' and the 1981 made-for-television film ''[[Murder in Texas]]''. ==Early life== Davis Ashton "Ash" Robinson studied dentistry at [[Newcomb–Tulane College|Tulane College]], [[New Orleans]], but disliked the subject and chose not to follow it as a career. Instead, he embarked on a series of business ventures, making and losing several fortunes before becoming an oilman. He met Rhea Ernestine Gardere in New Orleans,Thompson, 1976, pp. 5–28{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/23/obituaries/rhea-robinson-the-mother-in-blood-and-money-family.html |title=Rhea Robinson, the Mother In 'Blood and Money' Family |newspaper=The New York Times |publisher=The New York Times Company |date=June 23, 1987 |accessdate=August 2, 2014}}{{cite news|last=Hoge |first=Tom |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1314&dat=19770109&id=ijtOAAAAIBAJ&sjid=qe0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=5264,3143972 |title=Capote's technique tells murder well |publisher=The Spokesman-Review |date=January 9, 1977 |accessdate=August 9, 2014 |page=25}} and they married on July 28, 1919. After settling in Houston, the couple discovered that Rhea was unable to bear children, and Ash suggested that they should adopt a child instead. In March 1931, Rhea visited the [[Gladney Center for Adoption|Edna Gladney Home]] in [[Fort Worth, Texas|Fort Worth]] where she was introduced to the one-month-old Joan Olive, who had been given up for adoption by her unmarried mother. The Robinsons adopted the baby girl. The journalist Thomas Thompson writes that, as a child, Joan "was as well attended as a czarina". A keen horsewoman, she began riding at age three. At five, she won her first ribbon in [[equitation]] at the [[Houston Livestock Show and Rodeo]], coming in third on Dotty, an aging horse that her father had bought for her. It was the first of many contests she entered on Dotty in horse shows across the [[Southern United States]].{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/854751/joan_robinson_hill_age_7_horse_show/|title=3,500 Attend Horse Show|publisher=Brownsville Herald|date=July 5, 1938|page=8|accessdate=August 22, 2014|via = [[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} By the age of seven, she was regularly competing at an amateur level on three- and five-[[Horse gait|gaited]] horses, and she continued to achieve success, attaining first or second place in almost every contest she entered between 1938 and 1945. ==Career and first marriages== {{Expand section|date=October 2014}} [[File:Joan Robinson and Beloved Belinda trophy 1953.jpg|thumb|Robinson and Beloved Belinda, winners in the five-gaited competition at the Pin Oak Charity Horse Show, Houston, 1953]] Joan attended [[Stephens College]] in [[Columbia, Missouri]], where she was an average student with an active social life. Her father leased a suite of rooms at a hotel close to the campus, and installed his wife there, visiting on a regular basis himself. When Joan started acting in amateur college productions, she was approached by a talent scout working for [[Metro–Goldwyn–Mayer]] who offered her a screen test. Ash refused to permit her to take up the invitation, believing Hollywood to be full of predators who would take advantage of the girl. While in college, she married twice, both times before the age of 20. She married Spike Benton, who had a promising career as a [[United States Navy|Navy]] pilot, then New Orleans lawyer and childhood friend Cecil Burglass. Her father did not approve of her choices, and each marriage lasted little more than six months. Joan competed professionally throughout the 1950s and 1960s, winning as many as 500 trophies on her horses Beloved Belinda and Precious Possession. She had a riding habit made in the same color as Beloved Belinda, described by Thompson as "a lustrous pearl gray",Thompson 1976, pp. 37–38 which she wore at shows. ==Marriage to John Hill== On September 28, 1957, Joan married Dr. John Hill,{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/831253/joan_robinson_hill_marriage/?|title=Houston Wedding|date=September 29, 1957|page=20|accessdate=August 7, 2014|publisher=Valley Morning Star|via = [[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} described by the ''[[Houston Chronicle]]'' as "one of the city's leading plastic surgeons".{{cite news|first=J.R. |last=Gonzales |url=http://blog.chron.com/bayoucityhistory/2009/03/40-years-later-joan-robinson-hill/ |title=40 years later: Joan Robinson Hill |publisher=Houston Chronicle |date=March 19, 2009 |accessdate=August 2, 2014}} [[File:John Hill 1956.jpg|thumb|left|John Hill in 1956]] John Robert Hill (1931–1972) was the second of three children born to farmer Robert Raymond Hill, and his wife, Myra Hannah (Rice) Hill, of [[Edcouch, Texas]].{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/831241/john_hills_family_and_fiance_joan/?|title=Edcouch Notes|date=September 22, 1957|page=22|accessdate=August 7, 2014|publisher=Valley Morning Star|via = [[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}}{{cite news|first=Thomas |last=Thompson |url=https://newspaperarchive.com/us/texas/san-antonio/san-antonio-light/1977/02-06/page-25 |title=A true story of murder, passion and power in Houston |newspaper=San Antonio Light |page=25 |date=February 6, 1977 |accessdate=August 29, 2014 |via=Newspaper Archive |subscription=yes}} At their mother's insistence, all three Hill children received piano lessons, with John and Julian becoming gifted musicians.Thompson 1976, pp. 37–48 Hill studied a [[liberal arts]] course at [[Abilene Christian College]], where he graduated [[summa cum laude]]; he then attended [[Baylor College of Medicine]] in Houston.{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/831553/john_hill_baylor_graduate_1956/|title=Graduated|publisher=Valley Morning Star|date=June 7, 1956|page=3|accessdate=August 22, 2014|via = [[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}}{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/?spot=830189|title='Blood and Money' Is Bigger Than Texas|author=Hart, Bill|publisher=Abilene Reporter-News|date=October 24, 1976|accessdate=August 7, 2014|via = [[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} After graduating, he took a residency in surgery at Houston's [[Memorial Hermann Healthcare System|Hermann Hospital]]. During the 1950s, Houston-based surgeons such as [[Michael E. DeBakey]] and [[Denton Cooley]] were pioneering new heart surgery techniques, attracting a high volume of medical residents who wished to study under their tutelage. Realizing that the city would soon be awash with cardiac surgeons, Hill looked at alternative surgical careers, eventually opting for plastic surgery. At the time, only ten certified plastic surgeons were practicing in Houston, and Hill believed he could make more money in the profession. He was a popular member of the residency program, but almost had his medical career cut short after [[Gastrointestinal perforation|perforating a patient's bowel]] during a routine operation, then stitching the man up without repairing the damage. The patient later died of [[peritonitis]], and Hill received a severe reprimand after an autopsy uncovered his mistake. Upon completing his residency, Hill was offered a partnership by Nathan Roth, a [[New York City]]-trained surgeon who had established himself in Houston, and he joined the practice in 1963. Hill's partnership with Roth got off to a difficult start after he failed to warn his first patient that a drill bit had broken off during a jaw repair operation, leaving it embedded in the patient's face. When challenged by Roth, Hill was apologetic about his error, saying he had been "hesitant to mention this mistake on my very first case".Thompson 1976, pp 54–60 Hill's brother, Julian, had committed suicide shortly before the incident, and Roth gave Hill the benefit of the doubt because of this.{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/908070/julian_hill_obit_1963/|title=Dr. Juliam M. Hill obituary|date=May 27, 1963|page=2|publisher=Valley Morning Star|accessdate=August 26, 2014|via = [[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} The partnership between Hill and Roth was dissolved in 1967 after Roth grew tired of the other surgeon's repeated requests that Roth cover for him so that he could give music recitals. Hill then established his own practice in the same building as his former business partner.Thompson 1976, pp. 68–70 The Hills became a regular part of Houston's social scene, but largely led separate lives. For the first six years of their marriage, they lived at Ash Robinson's property, moving from there only after a fellow surgeon suggested the idea to John.Thompson 1976, pp. 54–60 Joan continued to focus on her equestrian career, while John devoted his spare time to performing and listening to music.Thompson 1976, pp. 49–52 When Joan officially retired Beloved Belinda, the event made national headlines. ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' reported that a band played "[[Auld Lang Syne]]" while Joan led Belinda, covered in a blanket of red roses, around the show ring at the Pin Oak horse show for the last time in 1959.{{cite journal|url=https://www.si.com/vault/1959/06/29/604052/joan-robinson-hill-and-beloved-belinda|title=Joan Robinson Hill and Beloved Belinda|publisher=Sports Illustrated|date=June 29, 1959|accessdate=August 3, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://pinoak.org/|title=Pin Oak Charity Horse Show|accessdate=August 24, 2014}} A groom who was present commented to his wife that "[[Abraham Lincoln|Abe Lincoln]] hisself didn't have a funeral as good as this one."Thompson 1976, pp. 56 ==Later years and illness== ===The Kirby Drive house and the music room=== On June 14, 1960, the Hills had a son, whom they named Robert Ashton Hill, but who was quickly nicknamed Boot by his grandfather.Thompson 1976, pp. 52–53 Robinson then bought his daughter a farm after she told him of her ambition to breed horses and establish a riding school. The property, named Chatsworth Farm, was opened in 1963, and became the scene of an annual spring picnic for Houston's doctors and their families.Thompson 1976, pp. 63–64{{cite web|url=http://law.justia.com/cases/texas/court-of-criminal-appeals/1982/57536-3.html|title=Paulus vs State|year=1981|publisher=Justia.com|accessdate=August 23, 2014}}{{#tag:ref|The name Chatsworth Farm was chosen because Robinson Hill's great-great-great grandfather, Louis Riviere Francois Gardere, had a plantation in [[Baton Rouge, Louisiana]] by that name. Gardere built one of the first horse racing tracks in the United States there.{{cite news |url=http://www.jimusnr.com/mitnews4.jpg |title=Beautiful Equestrienne Led Nation's Show Rings |author=Ewing, Betty |publisher=Houston Press |date=January 11, 1960 |page=15 |accessdate=August 25, 2014 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140825234052/http://www.jimusnr.com/mitnews4.jpg |archivedate=August 25, 2014 |df= }}|name=Chatsworth|group=note}} In 1965, the Hills also bought a house at 1561 Kirby Drive, a Southern colonial-style house located in the wealthy suburb of [[River Oaks, Houston|River Oaks]], a few blocks from the Robinsons' home.Thompson 1976, pp. 64–65 John Hill, whose interest in music began in childhood, was proficient on the piano as well as the [[trombone]], [[tuba]], [[flute]], and [[recorder (musical instrument)|recorder]].{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/831369/john_hills_mother_conducts_ladies/|title=Ladies Bible Class Is Entertained By Mrs. R. E. Hill|date=September 6, 1942|page=33|publisher=Brownsville Herald|via = [[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} As a young man, he aspired to become a piano player for a dance band, but his mother steered both sons toward medicine. Hill dedicated at least twenty hours a week to his interest in music–taking lessons, practicing, and participating in concerts. He was an active member of several groups, including the Houston Brass Quintet and the Heartbeats.Thompson 1976, pp. 60–61{{#tag:ref|He was later asked to leave the group after taking Ann Kurth along to one of their concerts and introducing her as his fiancée, something that offended the [[Conservatism|conservative]] wives of the band members.Thompson 1976, pp. 85–87|name=group|group=note}} Following the success of his own practice, he announced to Joan that he wished to convert a former servant's room into a "music room" at their house. Hill asked Ash Robinson to loan him $10,000 for the project, but Robinson refused as he believed it to be frivolous, and Hill already had a loan from him to buy the house.Thompson 1976, pp. 69–71 Hill then arranged for a bank loan, enabling him to pay off the money Robinson had loaned the couple to buy the Kirby Drive house, then commissioned a sound engineer to create the music room, telling him "I want the finest music room since [[Italian Renaissance|Renaissance Italy]]." Its estimated $10,000 cost was quickly exceeded, and by October 1968, Hill had spent $75,000 on the venture.Thompson 1976, p. 82 One of his ambitions was to own a handmade [[Bösendorfer]] piano, the world's most expensive. On hearing that a local firm had obtained the Austrian company's Houston franchise, he ordered an [[Imperial Bösendorfer (piano)|Imperial Grand]] for $15,000. The Bösendorfer was delivered in March 1969 and installed beside a [[Yamaha grand piano|Yamaha grand]] belonging to Joan.Thompson 1976, pp. 89–90 Having cost in excess of $100,000, in March 1969 John Hill's music room was almost complete. It became a ballroom-sized room with a double-height ceiling full of Renaissance-type frescoes, with [[Baccarat (company)|Baccarat]] crystal chandeliers. The carved marble fireplace was taken from an old Louisiana plantation home. Hill chose parquet flooring and a gold and white color scheme for the entire room. The pianos were placed at one end, with French provincial sofas cushioned by an oriental carpet at the other end. Gold and white silk wall panels concealed shelves for records, music-related books, and Hill's musical instruments. Hill had 108 speakers installed in the room, connected with four miles of wiring. He spent more than $20,000 on the room's sound system. Hill also added a hidden movie screen on which to project his collection of comedy films, which was also hidden behind one of the silk wall panels.Thompson 1976, pp. 90 The room became a bone of contention; Joan was angry about the amount of money her husband had poured into realizing his dream.Thompson 1976, pp. 90–92 During their 1968 separation, she had confided in Patti Gordon, a friend who owned a restaurant, that the music room had been central to their troubles. "He doesn't care about me or our son or anybody else. Only that god damned music room. I wish we had never started building it."Thompson 1976 pp. 86 Meanwhile, Chatsworth Farm did not achieve the success that Joan had envisaged, and was not turning a profit. A trainer had worked there until 1967, but he left because he did not get on with Robinson, and by 1969 Robinson was considering selling the place. Joan wanted to keep it running, however, and persuaded Diane Settegast, a friend from Dallas, to take on the temporary role of trainer.Thompson 1976, pp. 90–91 ===Marital problems=== By 1968, the Hills had begun to have significant conflicts in their marriage. Hill had embarked on an extramarital affair with Ann Kurth, a thrice-divorced mother of three sons whom he met when they were both collecting their respective children from [[summer camp]] in August 1968.{{cite news |last=Arrillaga |first=Pauline |url=http://airwolf.lmtonline.com/news/archive/0319/pagea6.pdf |title=‘Blood and Money’ mystery endures |publisher=Laredo Morning Times |date=March 19, 1999 |accessdate=August 2, 2014 |page=6A |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131020030933/http://airwolf.lmtonline.com/news/archive/0319/pagea6.pdf |archivedate=October 20, 2013 |df= }}{{cite news|last=Buck |first=Jerry |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=861&dat=19810122&id=vFAdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_FcEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6731,4752715 |title=Different view projected in murder story |publisher=The Victoria Advocate |date=January 22, 1981 |accessdate=August 3, 2014 |page=18}}{{cite news|last=Thompson |first=Thomas |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/134013812/?terms=husband%27s%2Binfidelity%2Bmarks |title=Husband's infidelity marks beginning of the end |publisher=The Palm Beach Post |date=February 7, 1977 |accessdate=August 3, 2014 |pages=13–20}}(subscription required) Kurth and Hill became romantically involved a short time after their meeting at the camp.{{#tag:ref|Hill and Kurth had two differing stories on how their relationship began. Hill's version was that Kurth made a play for him at the camp. Kurth claimed that he boldly telephoned her the day after their initial tryst and told her that he would be taking up all her time from now on.Thompson 1976, p. 77|name=camp|group=note}} When Joan returned from a horse show outside of Houston, she found a note from her husband saying that he had left because things were "not good between us". She phoned her husband's office many times in search of a better explanation from him; Hill did not return his wife's calls. Ash Robinson suggested the use of a private detective to learn what John Hill was up to; Joan was against this idea. Two weeks after his leaving, Hill asked to meet with his wife for a talk. John Hill told his wife that he was having an affair, and that he was being blackmailed because of it. It was not long before Joan learned that the woman's name was Ann Kurth. Hill, who had been staying at Kurth's home, proceeded to rent a small apartment in Houston's Post Oak district.Thompson 1976, pp. 77–81 The couple was still living apart in November 1968, when Hill had divorce papers served on his wife.{{cite news|url=http://www.crimemagazine.com/hill-robinson-murders-1969 |title=The Hill-Robinson Murders – 1969 |publisher=Crime Magazine |date= |accessdate=August 2, 2014}}Thompson 1976, p. 87Thompson 1976, pp. 82–87 Ash Robinson, who had hired detectives to investigate his son-in-law, learned of his Post Oak apartment from their report. Joan told her father that she still wanted to make her marriage work, despite her husband's infidelity, and contested the divorce.{{cite web|url=http://law.jrank.org/pages/3209/John-Hill-Trial-1971-Motive-Failed-Divorce.html|title=John Hill Trial 1971: Failed Divorce|publisher=jrank.org|accessdate=August 6, 2014}} In early December 1968, Ash Robinson phoned Hill at his Post Oak apartment, asking Hill to meet with him at the Robinson home. Robinson had drafted a letter of apology and a reconciliation offer to his daughter he wanted Hill to sign. Hill was in debt to Robinson for household and professional expenses, and his father-in-law implied that he would begin pressing for repayment if Hill did not return to his wife. Hill signed the letter written by Ash Robinson and prepared to go back to the Kirby Drive home.Thompson 1976, p. 83-107 Hill withdrew his divorce petition when the couple reconciled shortly before Christmas of that year. Not long after his return, Kurth began pressing Hill, telling him that if he stayed with Joan, Kurth would no longer be a part of his life. He continued to see Kurth after returning to live with his wife.Thompson 1976, pp. 87 Diane Settegast and Eunice Woolen, who stayed with the Hills as house guests a week before Joan's death, would later describe how Hill brought home [[pastry|pastries]], but insisted on choosing which ones each of them would eat.{{#tag:ref|The women were friends of Joan Robinson Hill. Settegast, a riding instructor, had been Chatsworth Farm's manager from September 1968 to February 1969. She was in Houston to talk with Ash Robinson about returning to a position at the farm.Thompson 1976, pp. 96–108|name=friends|group=note}} Hill would return home with the pastries in the evenings after being called away by a message on his [[pager]].{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2194&dat=19810711&id=rKMyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4u4FAAAAIBAJ&pg=1193,504369|title=Two wives later, death catches up with doctor|author=Haines, Max|date=July 11, 1981|publisher=Ottawa Citizen|page=88|accessdate=August 8, 2014}} On Friday, March 14, the Hills attended Houston's annual wild game dinner, where John played a concert with the Heartbeats. They left early, and on the way home Joan asked her husband if he would be staying out all night again. When he said that he probably would, she reminded him that he had done this on two previous occasions that week. The conversation quickly descended into an argument in which she told him that if he did stay out, he should not bother to come back. When they arrived home, she got out of the car, and he began to drive away, at which point she became angry and shouted "You've blown it, John! You've just lost your wife, your son and your god damn music room."Thompson 1976, pp. 95–97 Shortly before the arrival of her house guests, Joan had learned that her husband was still maintaining his small apartment and still involved with Ann Kurth. On the day following the argument, Hill took his son for a haircut, and during the drive, they went to his apartment to pick up some things; the boy talked with his mother about it when he arrived home. Joan invited her friend and neighbor Vann Maxwell over to discuss the matter, and when she arrived, announced an impromptu game of [[Contract bridge|bridge]] with Settegast and Woolen in the music room. John Hill was listening to music at one end of the room while the women played cards at the other. Joan began loudly discussing her husband, then slipping into silence whenever he approached. She told the women that she was planning to consult a lawyer on Monday, and Maxwell became uneasy with the situation. She asked Joan to be quiet or she would leave. Joan then started writing notes to her friend, in which she repeated her intention to speak to a lawyer, and to take John out of her [[Will and testament|will]].Thompson 1976, pp. 99–101Thompson 1976, pp. 103–104 After a tense evening, Hill put on a romantic record and came over to stand behind his wife's chair. Settegast suggested the couple should dance, and they did. Afterwards they retired to bed. The next morning, Joan told Settegast that Hill had made her "very happy" the previous night. "He told me things I've never heard from the man before in our whole married life. I think it's going to be all right between us from now on." ===Illness=== Settegast and Woolen recalled a conversation they had with Joan after she rose late on the afternoon of Saturday, March 15. She told them that "John gave me some pill last night and it really knocked me out". She spent most of the following day in bed after she vomited her breakfast.Thompson 1976, pp. 101–102 After checking on her several times, Hill told the two house guests that he was going out to purchase medication for her. Hill took his son and the two women out for dinner that evening, but Joan was too sick to join them. Hill bought her a carton of orange juice on the way home, then went to visit a friend. Joan continued to be ill, vomiting several more times. On Monday, March 17, Settegast and Woolen came to say goodbye to Joan, as they were returning to Dallas. Joan told the women she felt dehydrated and asked for some water. She told her friends she would be all right as they prepared to leave.Thompson 1976, p. 108 Effie Green, the Hills' maid, was told that Mrs. Hill was sick in bed and was not to be disturbed for any reason. On the morning of Tuesday, March 18, Effie went to check on Joan after the doctor had left for the day. She found Joan in a soiled nightgown; when she moved her to help her change into a fresh gown, Effie saw that Joan had been lying in dried feces. Two towels had been placed under her due to a recent loose bowel movement that appeared to contain blood. The maid did her best to help Joan into the bathroom to clean her. As she did this, Effie noticed that Joan's face began turning blue. The maid hurriedly cleaned up Joan and the soiled bed and called to her husband, who also worked for the Hills, to phone Mrs. Hill's parents' home at once. When there was no answer, Archie Green tried unsuccessfully to reach John Hill at his office and left a message. Rhea Robinson was unaware of Joan's condition when her husband dropped her off at the Hill home to visit her daughter.Thompson 1976, pp. 108–111 The severity of Joan's illness was known only to those in the Hill household until the morning of March 18, 1969, when her mother entered her daughter's sickroom. She found Joan lying in her own body wastes and vomit as John Hill stood at the foot of his wife's bed. When Robinson found that her daughter had a fever, Hill told his mother-in-law he thought Joan should be taken to a hospital. Hill did not summon an ambulance for his wife, who was now semiconscious, but insisted on driving her to the hospital himself. The hospital he chose was not one of Houston's noted medical centers, but a new hospital in Houston's suburbs, [[Greater Sharpstown, Houston|Sharpstown]] General Hospital, which was a forty-five-minute drive from the Hill home.Sizer 2000, pp. 40–41{{#tag:ref|The largest medical center in the world, [[Texas Medical Center]], was a 15-minute drive from the Hill home.Sizer 2000, p. 41 John Hill was practicing at [[Memorial Hermann Healthcare System|Hermann Hospital]], part of Texas Medical Center, at the time he and Joan were married.{{cite web|url=http://health.usnews.com/best-hospitals/area/tx/memorial-hermann-texas-medical-center-6741890|title=Memorial Hermann-Texas Medical Center|publisher=US News & World Report|accessdate=August 8, 2014}}|name=center|group=note}}{{#tag:ref|The hospital was since renamed Bayou City Medical Center and River Oaks South; it was closed in 2008.{{cite news|url=http://www.chron.com/business/article/River-Oaks-Hospital-closes-its-two-units-1586997.php|title=River Oaks closes its two units|date=June 24, 2008|author=Cook, Lynn|publisher=Houston Chronicle|accessdate=August 2, 2014}}|name=hospitalclosed|group=note}} The hospital had no [[Emergency department|emergency room]] or [[intensive care unit]] at the time of Joan's admission. She was brought into the hospital by a nurse who had come to the car with a wheelchair and was taken to a private room on arrival.Sizer 2000, p. 74 During the drive, Joan told her mother she was going blind; her husband referred to this as a "blackout". Upon arrival at Sharpstown General, Robinson Hill's [[blood pressure]] was 60/40; the hospital nurse promptly took a second reading, as she believed that she had made some sort of error. After determining that the reading was correct, the nurse believed Joan was in [[Shock (circulatory)|shock]] and placed a call to Dr. Walter Bertinot, who was named as his wife's attending physician by John Hill. Bertinot, who knew Joan only socially, had no reason to believe she was seriously ill until the call from the hospital nurse. Hill had described his wife's symptoms as [[nausea]], vomiting, and [[diarrhea]]; Bertinot initially thought she was suffering from [[influenza]]. When Bertinot arrived in Joan's hospital room, she recognized him and made reference to a party which they had both attended. Bertinot ordered [[Intravenous therapy|IV fluids]], took another history, and now believed she had a case of [[foodborne illness]].Sizer 2000, pp. 74–75 Still uneasy after his second diagnosis, Dr. Bertinot consulted a colleague, Dr. Frank Lanza, who believed Joan to be in [[septic shock]]. The doctors ordered [[blood culture]]s, which would take 72 hours to process.{{#tag:ref|The results of the blood culture for Robinson Hill taken as a hospital patient was negative.Thompson 1976, p. 139 However, having a negative result does not mean that bacteria were not present. It can take a series of blood cultures before bacteria are discovered.{{cite web|title=Current Blood Culture Methods and Systems: Clinical Concepts, Technology, and Interpretation of Results|url=http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/23/1/40.full.pdf+html|page=41|author=Weinstein, Melvin P.|publisher=Clinical Infectious Diseases|year=1996|accessdate=August 8, 2014}}([[PDF]])|name=culture|group=note}} Joan had been a patient at Sharpstown General for six hours when her kidneys began to fail; she was not passing any [[urine]] and had [[edema]]. Her intravenous fluids were increased with the hope of being able to prompt her kidneys into producing urine. By 8 p.m., Joan Robinson Hill's kidneys had failed to respond and her condition was considered to be "grave". Dr. Bernard Hicks, a [[kidney]] specialist, was called in to consult. Dr. Hicks determined Joan was in severe [[Renal failure|kidney failure]]. Since Sharpstown General had no [[Hemodialysis|dialysis]] machine, the medical team debated about transferring Joan to [[Houston Methodist Hospital]], where such equipment was available, but Dr. Hicks believed she was too ill to be transferred. The option for treating her at the hospital was to begin [[Kidney dialysis#Peritoneal dialysis|peritoneal dialysis]]. Dr. Hicks wanted the consent of John Hill before beginning this procedure and phoned him at the Kirby Drive home at 9:15 p.m. Hill left the house after taking the telephone call but did not arrive at Sharpstown General to give his consent until 11 p.m. His wife was conscious and begged him to stay with her, saying that she was frightened.Thompson 1976, pp. 115–116 Dr. Bertinot checked on Joan at 12:30 a.m. on March 19. While she had not improved, she appeared to have stabilized. Her blood pressure had elevated slightly and she was responding to the peritoneal dialysis. Bertinot felt he could now leave the hospital to get some rest, but Dr. Lanza said he would stay a while longer and would call Dr. Bertinot if anything should change. John Hill also felt he could get some sleep and retired to a couch in a hospital records room. By 1:30 a.m., both Dr. Lanza and Dr. Hicks had left the hospital. Joan, who had been heavily sedated, was coherent at times. When Hill told her he would be down the hall if needed, she asked the nurse attending her to see that her husband was made comfortable there.Thompson 1976, pp. 116–117 ==Death, investigation, trials== {{main|Death of Joan Robinson Hill}} ===Death=== At 2:30 a.m. on March 19, the attending nurse noticed that Joan's [[vital signs]] indicated sudden heart failure. She ran to the room's doorway and shouted to the nurses' station to have the resident on duty come immediately with cardiac failure equipment. As she did this, Joan slightly raised her head, gasping her husband's name. As she tried to breathe, a flood of blood rushed from her mouth. The resident tried to save her by injecting [[Epinephrine|adrenaline]] into her heart; but he was not successful.{{cite news|url=http://www.apnewsarchive.com/1985/Ash-Robinson-Dies-In-Florida-Hospital/id-4361e2768358c89a8e42d062ba5c4094 |title=Ash Robinson Dies In Florida Hospital |agency=Associated Press |date=February 16, 1985 |accessdate=August 2, 2014}} ===First autopsy=== Texas state law at the time required an autopsy, before any embalming or burial could take place, for anyone who died in a hospital within twenty-four hours of admission. Dr. Bertinot spoke to John Hill about the legal need for an autopsy. Hill asked Jim Oates to call a local funeral home to claim Robinson Hill's body. Less than four hours after her death, the funeral home removed Robinson Hill's body from the hospital.Thompson 1976, pp. 118–119 Within an hour after moving the body from Sharpstown General, the funeral home began the process of [[embalming]] Robinson Hill's body. The hospital's pathologist, Dr. Arthur Morse, arrived at the funeral home at 10 a.m. to carry out the autopsy, only to find that the body had already been embalmed. Morse concluded his autopsy at 11:30 a.m. without finding any signs of what caused Robinson Hill's death aside from a maroon coloration of her [[pancreas]] and offered an opinion that she may have died from [[pancreatitis]].Evans 2007, p. 84 ===Second autopsy=== Since receiving Dr. Morse's opinion that his daughter had died from pancreatitis, Robinson had been consulting doctors on the matter, who had advised him that this was an unlikely cause of death. On the morning of Friday, March 21, the day of Joan Robinson Hill's funeral, Ash Robinson visited the office of Assistant District Attorney [[I. D. McMaster]], where he accused John Hill of killing his wife, telling McMaster of the circumstances surrounding her death and autopsy. McMaster asked Harris County Medical Examiner Joseph Jachimczyk to go to the funeral home to examine the body before the funeral. Jachimczyk ordered Morse to hand over blood and urine specimens taken from Robinson Hill. He then drove to the funeral home to view the body.Thompson 1976, pp. 119–125 Jachimczyk delivered his report on the second autopsy at the end of March, ruling out any poisoning, and concluding, "it is my opinion based upon a reasonable probability that the cause of death is due to acute focal [[hepatitis]], probably viral in origin."Thompson 1976, pp. 129–134 On reading the report, McMaster felt there was no case, but Robinson refused to believe that no crime had been committed. He hired lawyer Frank Briscoe, a former [[Harris County, Texas|Harris County]] District Attorney. Robinson petitioned his son-in-law to give permission for Joan's body to be exhumed for another autopsy, but Hill refused.Thompson 1976, pp. 134–136 ===Third autopsy=== Ash Robinson then hired Dr. Milton Helpern, the chief medical examiner for New York City at the time,Evans 2007, pp. 87–91 to come to Houston to examine Robinson Hill's body. An autopsy was also requested by a Harris County [[grand jury]] investigating Robinson Hill's death. That autopsy was performed by a team of ten doctors led by Dr. Robert Bucklin, who was then the medical examiner for [[Galveston County, Texas|Galveston County]], and including Dr. Helpern, who was deputized as an acting Harris County [[medical examiner]].{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=861&dat=19691011&id=1wFaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=FEsNAAAAIBAJ&pg=4756,1865525|title=Houston Socialite's Death Seen As Result Meningitis|date=October 11, 1969|publisher=Victoria Advocate|page=5B|accessdate=August 8, 2014}} Helpern examined the body of Joan Robinson Hill for seven and a half hours, then went back to New York with his tissue samples, saying he would issue a report on his findings at a later date. The series of autopsies indicated that Robinson Hill had suffered a "massive infection" from an undetermined source, but because the body had been embalmed before an initial examination was conducted, an exact cause of death could not be identified. Dr. Bucklin listed Robinson Hill's cause of death as [[meningitis]] and [[septicemia]]. Following the autopsy, Joseph Jachimczyk issued a fresh report in which he observed "It is now my opinion that Joan Robinson Hill came to her death as a result of a fulminating infectious process, the specific nature of which is no longer determinable."{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1499&dat=19801124&id=XDUqAAAAIBAJ&sjid=visEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7035,2177993 |title=Toxic shock suspected in death of heiress |publisher=The Milwaukee Journal |date=November 24, 1980 |accessdate=August 2, 2014 |page=9}}Thompson 1976, pp. 169{{Cite web|url=https://www.texasarchive.org/library/index.php?title=2015_02478|title=Joan and John Hill Murder Investigations|last=KPRC-TV|first=|date=1970|website=Texas Archive of the Moving Image|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-25}} Dr. Helpern's report, issued in April 1970, noted that John Hill's treatment of his wife at home and the delay in seeking specialized medical attention at a hospital were factors in the death of Robinson Hill.{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/830641/john_hill_indicted_1970/|title=Doctor Indicted In Wife's Death|date=May 23, 1970|publisher=Abilene Reporter-News|page=6|accessdate=August 8, 2014|via = [[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} ===Prosecution and murder of John Hill=== After Robinson Hill's death, Hill married Ann Kurth in June 1969, but divorced Kurth less than a year later, shortly before he was indicted for the murder of Robinson Hill. Following Hill's marriage to Kurth, Ash Robinson accused his former son-in-law of poisoning his daughter,{{cite news|last=Wilkins |first=Barbara |url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20066953,00.html |title=A Texas Heiress Dies, and Tommy Thompson Spins a Tale of Violence, Love and Intrigue |publisher=People Magazine |date=October 4, 1976 |accessdate=August 2, 2014}} and petitioned the District Attorney to launch a murder investigation. A grand jury began hearing evidence in the summer of 1969, and retired without indicting Hill. District Attorney [[Carol Vance]] then put the case before a second grand jury, which ordered an exhumation of the body.Thompson 1976, pp. 148–159 In February 1970, the case was heard by a third grand jury.{{Cite web|url=https://www.texasarchive.org/library/index.php?title=2015_02478|title=Joan and John Hill Murder Investigations|last=KPRC-TV|first=|date=1970|website=Texas Archive of the Moving Image|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-25}} This panel heard testimony from Ann Kurth, who told them that Hill had confessed to killing his wife and had also tried to kill Kurth on three occasions.Thompson 1976, pp. 174–188 Helpern presented his findings to the grand jury in April 1970. McMaster and his fellow Assistant District Attorney, [[Ernie Ernst]], believed that Hill had murdered his wife but that there was not enough evidence to indict him. Ernst suggested that they could try him for failing to provide an adequate level of care, which had resulted in her death. The jury voted 10–2 to indict Hill for murder by omission, deciding that he had "willfully, intentionally and culpably" contributed to his wife's death because he had not given her sufficient medical help.Thompson 1976, pp. 189–209 The state of Texas had not previously indicted anyone on a charge of murder by omission. Hill's murder trial began on February 15, 1971. Kurth testified against Hill, claiming that he had tried to kill her on June 30, 1969, by crashing their car into a bridge, and by injecting her with a [[hypodermic syringe]].{{cite news|last=Thompson |first=Thomas |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/134013972/?terms=uncovering%2Ba%2Bmurder |title=Uncovering a murder case |publisher=The Palm Beach Post |date=February 8, 1977 |accessdate=August 3, 2014 |pages=49–53}}(subscription required) She also told the court that he had confessed to killing Robinson Hill, explaining in detail how he had allegedly done it by lacing pastries with infectious bacteria and later injecting Robinson Hill with the same bacteria. As a result of Kurth's testimony, Hill's attorney was granted a request for a mistrial. Hill's second trial was eventually scheduled for November 1972.{{cite news|last=Thompson |first=Thomas |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/134014210/?terms=hill%27s%2Bhappiness%2Bonly%2Btemporary |title=Hill's happiness only temporary |publisher=The Palm Beach Post |date=February 9, 1977 |accessdate=August 5, 2014 |page=21}}(subscription required) On September 24, 1972, a few weeks before the second trial was to start, Hill was shot dead by a masked gunman during a robbery at his mansion as Hill and his third wife, Connie, returned home from a medical conference in [[Las Vegas]].{{cite news|first=J.R. |last=Gonzales |url=http://blog.chron.com/bayoucityhistory/2012/09/40-years-later-dr-john-hills-scandalous-saga/#7478101=0 |title=40 years later: Dr. John Hill’s scandalous saga |publisher=Houston Chronicle |date=September 24, 2012 |accessdate=August 2, 2014}} ====Involvement of Bobby Vandiver, Marcia McKittrick, and Lilla Paulus==== Bobby Wayne Vandiver was arrested for Hill's murder in April 1973,Thompson 1976, pp. 314–317 but refused to cooperate with police until he was positively identified as the perpetrator by Hill's mother.{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/134014600/?terms=Dr.%2BJohn%2BHill%27s%2Bkiller|title=Dr. John Hill's killer links case to Ash Robinson |publisher=The Palm Beach Post |date=February 10, 1977 |accessdate=August 7, 2014 |pages=33, 49}}(subscription required) When he confessed to the murder, he told police that he had done it for financial gain, and that the shooting was a contract killing that he had been asked to carry out for $5,000. During his confession, Vandiver implicated Marcia McKittrick and Lilla Paulus as having been accessories to Hill's murder. On April 25, 1973, a grand jury voted to indict Vandiver and McKittrick for first degree murder, and indict Paulus as an accomplice to murder.Thompson 1976, pp. 331 Vandiver's trial was set for September 1973. The trial was eventually rescheduled for April 1974, but Vandiver failed to appear. He had moved to [[Longview, Texas]], adopting an alias. Longview police officer John Raymer grew suspicious of the newcomer to his town. After discovering the man's first name was actually Bobby, Raymer confronted Vandiver at a cafe one evening in May; Vandiver pulled a gun, and Raymer shot him dead.{{cite news|last=Thompson |first=Thomas |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/134015135/?terms=Third%2Bdeath%2Bgives%2BJoan%2BHill%2Bcase%2Banother%2Btwist |title=Third death gives Joan Hill case another twist |publisher=The Palm Beach Post |date=February 11, 1977 |accessdate=August 8, 2014 |pages=27, 30}}(subscription required)Thompson 1976, 344–355 Under questioning, McKittrick corroborated Vandiver's story.Thompson 1976, pp. 343 McKittrick was tried and convicted in 1974 of being Vandiver's getaway driver and given a ten-year jail sentence.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=861&dat=19771022&id=stZHAAAAIBAJ&sjid=FYAMAAAAIBAJ&pg=6992,4948731 |title=Robinson innocent of plotting death |publisher=The Victoria Advocate |date=October 22, 1977 |accessdate=August 2, 2014 |page=5}} She was paroled after serving five years.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=861&dat=19820527&id=GWVfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=GV4NAAAAIBAJ&pg=5898,7505324 |title= Paulus sentence upheld |publisher=The Victoria Advocate |date=May 27, 1982 |accessdate=August 2, 2014 |page=39}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=861&dat=19860725&id=EMMcAAAAIBAJ&sjid=G1kEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7061,6542662|title=Ex-convict McKittrick held on drunk charge|page=7A|date=July 25, 1986|publisher=The Victoria Advocate|accessdate=August 3, 2014}} Lilla Paulus was convicted and given a 35-year sentence.{{Cite web|url=https://www.texasarchive.org/library/index.php?title=2015_02478|title=Joan and John Hill Murder Investigations|last=KPRC-TV|first=|date=1975|website=Texas Archive of the Moving Image|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-25}}{{cite news|last=Thompson |first=Thomas |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/134015372/?terms=Ash%2BRobinson%27s%2Bname%2Bleft%2Buntainted%2Bafter%2Btrial |title=Ash Robinson's name left untainted after trial |publisher=The Palm Beach Post |date=February 12, 1977 |accessdate=August 9, 2014 |pages=20, 22–24}}(subscription required) She died of breast cancer at the [[Gatesville, Texas|Gatesville]] prison on May 16, 1986.{{cite news|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1986-06-01/news/8602020130_1_mrs-paulus-key-witness-blood-and-money|title=Texas Murder Conspirator Dies|date=June 1, 1986|publisher=Sun-Sentinel|accessdate=August 3, 2014}} ==Cultural impact== The events surrounding the death of Joan Robinson Hill have been the subject of several books, as well as a 1981 television film. Journalist and author Thomas Thompson's 1976 book ''Blood and Money'' provides a detailed account of the case. He became interested in the story while shadowing doctors in Houston as research for a previous book, ''Hearts'', about the world of cardiac surgery. Ann Kurth filed a $3-million lawsuit against Thompson over his description of her as a "provocatively dressed, heavily made-up woman", but her action was dismissed by a jury in [[Austin, Texas|Austin]] in March 1981, which decided that although derogatory, his description of her was accurate.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2519&dat=19821030&id=bnhiAAAAIBAJ&sjid=UXcNAAAAIBAJ&pg=2874,4586592|title='Celebrity' Author Dies of Cancer|publisher=Observer-Reporter Washington, PA|page=B-10|date=October 30, 1982|accessdate=August 2, 2014}} The legal case was one of three Thompson faced over his book.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/10/us/woman-is-denied-award-in-libel-suit.html |title=Woman Is Denied Award In Libel Suit |publisher=The New York Times Company |newspaper=The New York Times |date=March 10, 1981 |accessdate=August 3, 2014}} Kurth published her own account of the case entitled ''Prescription Murder'' in which she repeated her claim that Hill had tried to kill her, and alleged that he may have poisoned his first wife with bacteria-laced pastries.{{#tag:ref|Kurth further claimed that the suicide of Hill's brother, Julian, in 1963, was actually a murder by John Hill. Kurth wrote that Hill confessed to injecting his brother with an overdose of morphine because he was embarrassed by his brother's homosexuality. The official report states that the suicide resulted from a barbiturate overdose.{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/?spot=823787|title=Millionaire In Vengeance Killing Riddle Says: I'm Innocent|author=Brown, Charles|publisher=San Antonio Express|page=145|date=September 19, 1976|accessdate=August 5, 2014|via = [[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}}|name=Julian|group=note}} She also suggested that Hill had not been killed in 1972, and had instead moved to Mexico after faking his death.{{#tag:ref|While Kurth said she believed Hill was alive and living in Mexico, Thomas Thompson, the author of ''Blood and Money'', countered her claim by saying, "She has one eye on the cash register and no eye on the truth".{{cite news|title=Millionaire In Vengeance Killing Riddle Says: I'm Innocent|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/823787/joan_robinson_hill_1976_story_page_2/|author=Brown, Charles|publisher=San Antonio Express|page=144|date=September 19, 1976|accessdate=August 5, 2014|via = [[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}}|name=alive|group=note}} Retired Harris County District Attorney [[Carol Vance]] also discussed the case in his memoirs, ''Boomtown DA''. In 1981, the Robinson Hill case was the subject of ''Murder in Texas'', a television film featuring [[Farrah Fawcett]] as Robinson Hill.{{cite news|last=Buck |first=Jerry |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=861&dat=19810123&id=MNJHAAAAIBAJ&sjid=pX8MAAAAIBAJ&pg=1191,1762590 |title=Joan Robinson Hill character demanding role for Fawcett |publisher=The Victoria Advocate |date=April 23, 1981 |accessdate=August 2, 2014 |page=17}} It concurs with Kurth's theory that Hill may have faked his death, suggesting that he arranged for someone else to be killed in his place. The journalist Jerry Buck noted in an article preceding the film's debut on [[National Broadcasting Company|NBC]] that the face of the shooting victim had been battered and that there were anomalies in the autopsy report, notably that Hill had a different eye color from that recorded for the dead person. Buck also wrote that Hill was in financial difficulties with the [[Internal Revenue Service]] in 1972 and facing a murder case against him. Sightings of Hill had also been reported in Mexico and [[New York City]]. The death of Robinson Hill was also the subject of a true crime television documentary-drama as part of the series ''[[Behind Mansion Walls]]'' from the [[Investigation Discovery]] television network "Behind Mansion Walls: The Thoroughbred Heiress" S1 E13; first aired in June 2011.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2262629/?ref_=ttep_ep13|title=The Thoroughbred Heiress|publisher=Internet Movie Database|accessdate=August 8, 2014}} ==Notes== {{Reflist|group=note}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Sources== *{{cite book|title=Killer Doctors|publisher=Penguin Press|year=2007|isbn=978-1-10120-597-6|first=Colin|last=Evans}} *{{cite book|title=Texas Justice, Bought and Paid For|publisher=Taylor Trade Publications|year=2000|isbn= 978-1-46162-555-1|first=Mona D.|last=Sizer}} *{{cite book|title=Outrageous Texans: Tales of the Rich and Infamous|publisher=Taylor Trade Publications|year=2008|isbn=978-1-58979-402-3|first=Mona D.|last=Sizer}} *{{cite book|title=Blood and Money|publisher=New English Library|year=1976|edition=|isbn=|first=Thomas|last=Thompson}} *{{cite book|title=Blood and Money|publisher=Running Press|year=2001|edition=reprint|isbn=978-0-78670-947-2|first=Thomas|last=Thompson}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Robinson Hill, Joan}} [[Category:1931 births]] [[Category:1969 deaths]] [[Category:20th century American trials]] [[Category:20th-century American women]] [[Category:American adoptees]] [[Category:American female equestrians]] [[Category:American socialites]] [[Category:Crimes in Houston]] [[Category:Murder trials]] [[Category:People from Houston]] [[Category:Stephens College alumni]] [[Category:Unsolved deaths]]
